Key Match Events: Julian Álvarez scored in the 23rd minute to make it 1-0 for Argentina.
Lionel Messi scored in the 51st minute to make it 2-0 for Argentina.
Rodrigo De Paul was instrumental in Argentina shutting down the Canadian possession game, winning 9 out of 14 duels and making 2 key passes.
Pre-Game Insights: Argentina boss Lionel Scaloni made a few changes to the team that beat Ecuador, with Gonzalo Montiel coming in at right-back, Ángel Di María returning to the side on the wing, and Julian Álvarez getting the start up top ahead of Lautaro Martínez.

Canada's Jesse Marsch went with a similar lineup for his Canada squad as in prior matches, but he chose to put Ismaël Koné back into midfield after the youngster redeemed himself with some strong play and scored the winning penalty in the quarter-final against Venezuela.
Post-Match Reflections: Canada's men's national team fell in a hard-fought Copa América semifinal to Argentina, but they have nothing to be ashamed of, as they went toe-to-toe with the best side in international football.
The Canadians did not surrender at any point, desperate even to find one goal against the Argentines, but they could not make a dent in Argentina's defence.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Canada will get one more night at the party, in the third place game against either Colombia or Uruguay on Saturday.
The match was a testament to the challenge Canada posed, with Argentina's goalkeeper Emiliano Martínez resorting to time-wasting antics late in the match.
Others: Canada's dream run at the Copa América finally sputtered on Tuesday, as the men's national team fell in an admirable battle to Argentina in Tuesday's semifinal.
This marked an incredible run at this Copa América for the Canadian men's national team, earning incredible experience in the process by playing world-class opposition.
